;In her speech, Von der Leyen said global markets were â€œflooded with cheaper Chinese electric carsâ€ whose prices were â€œkept artificially low by huge state subsidiesâ€. This was distorting â€œour marketâ€ and was something the EU would â€œnot acceptâ€, she added.

;

;Von der Leyen announced an anti-subsidy investigation into Chinese electric cars and said: â€œEurope is open for competition, not for a race to the bottom.â€

;

;But she also confirmed industry fears of political tightropes. â€œEqually it is vital to keep open lines of communication and dialogue with China,â€ Von der Leyen said, referencing the EU's formal policy of â€œde-riskingâ€ and not â€œdecouplingâ€ from Beijing.

;

;Her warnings to China are also the strongest hint yet that the European Commission will bow to demands by UK and EU carmaker that a 10% tariff of electric vehicle exports within the the bloc is suspended to allow German, French, Italian, British and central European factories catch up with Chinese expertise.

;

;Setting out legislative goals for the next 100 days, Von der Leyen also touched on the threat and opportunities posed by artificial intelligence, saying EU leaders had a â€œnarrowing window of opportunityâ€ to guide the technology responsibly.

;

;She said getting the EU legislation on artificial intelligence, which is in its final stages, passed within the next 100 days was one of her priorities.
